args: Oh my, yes! Look at the logs of this ritual!\nPerhaps it has something to do with\nthe Progenitor!

A record from 500 years ago, is it?
Hmm, it doesn't use the name
＂Progenitor,＂ but it does indeed appear
to be referring to them with a codename.
WHEE HEE HEE HA HA HA HOO!\nI haven't devoted my life to the study of\nritual magic for nothing, you know!
Good. Let us hope there is something\nuseful there at the day's end.
That ritual is heretical, and thus forbidden.\nAs royalty, are you certain you wish to\ndelve further into such subjects?
One cannot find the truth without exploring\nthe realm of the taboo. Surely this is a\nconcept you are familiar with?
If our work here leads to a strategy against\nthe Progenitor, I care not how heretical\nthe means are to that end.
You're fortunate my companion isn't\naround to hear you say that.

Well then, I suppose I shall do as I please.
It isn't every day that one is able to throw
off the shackles of convention to such a
degree, after all!
You summoned us hence with cause,\ngood sir, yet I fear I know little in the\nmatter of physic or inquest.
All I ask is that you try. I would like you to\nlearn what you can about the Progenitor\nfrom the perspective of the Sandreach.

Aye, the history of my people is long and
longer still, and there may yet be clues
about that scapegrace hidden amongst our
many annals.

And while you're blowing dust off books
or whatever, I'll wrangle up the other
dunefolk and, like, get 'em to help!
Girl, we're gonna DO this thing!

I shouldn't be surprised that you could
supervise the many...unique types of
people here in the Halidom, dearie,
and yet I still find myself impressed.
You have been a great help as well,\nCassandra.

Well, I brought the results of Sinoa's
research. She would have come herself,
but the poor thing is still cleaning up the
more explosive results of her work.
You have my thanks. Perhaps space-time\nmagic will prove the key to sealing away\nthe Progenitor once and for all.
Forgive me, dearie, but didn't you already\nhave another plan in place for that?
One cannot have enough backup plans\nwhen it comes to a battle against the very\ncreator of the world.
Ha! You're clearly the son of that cautious\nAurelius, and no mistake! ...Hmm?
S-sorry to interrupt. I just had something\nI wanted to say to Prince Phares.
There is need for such formalities among\nwe fellows of science.
You are the mana observer Sophie, yes?\nWhat did you need?
Well, I'm not sure if this has anything to\ndo with the Progenitor, but I've noticed\nsomething about your own mana.
It's very slight—hardly noticeable unless I\nreally focus—but I sense a strange mana\nabout you that... Well, it isn't yours.
Were you aware of this, Phares?
Er, would you permit me to maybe look\ninto this some more? It might be having\nsome kind of effect on your body.
While I appreciate your concern,\nfurther research is unnecessary.
I imagine my mana simply changed as a\nresult of how the Progenitor used me.
We lack the time to look into anything\nother than what will help us in this fight,\nso my strange mana will need to wait.
Nicolas has written a detailed report,\nand Althemia has some rather perceptive\npoints to make as well...
Hmm? This is from Sophie. I specifically\ntold that woman not to bother looking into\nmy mana situation, and yet...
(Observations on the Effects on Mana\nFollowing Possession by the Progenitor.)
＂I suspect that Phares's mana has become\ncorrupted and changed by the influence of\nthe Progenitor, who uses black mana.＂
＂However, as far as I can observe, this\nseems to be causing no ill effects. In fact,\nthe mana appears to be protecting him.＂

＂I hypothesize that this unknown mana
may be a defense mechanism of his own
mana.＂
...An interesting theory.
(I could test whether it is acting as a\ndefense mechanism by infusing myself\nwith black mana! No, but before that—)
It seemed like you were still awake,\nso I brought you some tea. Er...is this\na good time?
Perfect, in fact; I am in need of a break.
I'm glad to hear... Oh! That's my report!
And a fascinating report it is.
I'm sorry! I know you told me we didn't\nhave the time to look into it, but I just\ncouldn't stop thinking about it!
I know all too well what it's like when an\nidea worms its way into one's mind.
And your report has piqued my curiosity\nabout this mysterious mana as well.

Scholars such as ourselves are drawn to
the unknown. When a mystery arises,
we cannot stop until we have uncovered
all there is to know about it.
Then why don't we look into it?
I know it doesn't have much to do with\nthe fight ahead, but it DOES have\nsomething to do with you.
Mana can carry people's thoughts and\nfeelings, so maybe yours is actually trying\nto tell you something!
But more than that, if this is something\nyou want to know, then it's something\nyou SHOULD know.
...I can't say I am entirely uninterested.
But as I said before, we lack the time for\nresearch that will do nothing save sating\nmy own curiosity.
Could you really just let this go?
The way I see it, the fact we lack the time\nmeans we should look into it more.
With so few days left to us, we should use\nthem to fulfill the things we truly want.
I observed your mana, so I know the state\nit's in. Your mana is stagnant, as if it's\nbeing restrained by something.
Mana is something that is meant to be\nas free as the wind. Your current situation\ncan't be good for you.
I believe the reason your mana has\nstagnated is internal—that the effect\nis psychological.
So please, listen to the voice of your heart.
And take care of yourself, all right?\nMana disruptions can affect the body.
(I haven't been free since the moment\nthe wyrmscale began ravaging my body.)
(What would I have done if I hadn't been\nafraid of death coming at any moment?\nIf I had always been...healthy?)
(I'd likely I have thrown myself\nwholeheartedly into my research, longing\nto find what truths this world may hide.)
Heh. Why am I thinking of my own wants\nat a time like this?
I don't have the time to ruminate about\nfreedom. Nothing can change this.
Right now, I must formulate what direction\nwe'll take in tomorrow's research.
(But I still am grateful for your\nconsideration, Sophie.)
